title: 5.0 out of 5 stars Impressive Sound and Functionality
author: ETaylor
content: I am impressed with everything about these earbuds.TL;DR--Great sound quality. Quite comfortable. Surprisingly good app. Easily customizable features. Consistent, reliable bluetooth connectivity. Overall, outstanding value.BACKGROUND: The last set of earbuds I owned were non-brand wireless buds that cost about $40 a couple years ago, and they were garbage. In the meantime, I've used a pair of compact Bose on-ear wireless headphones, which are incredibly comfortable and provide amazing sound clarity, but I wanted something smaller and easier to carry around for use at the office. All further remarks about these Anker earbuds are in comparison to my Bose headphones.SOUND: The clarity and quality of sound these earbuds produce is remarkable. It's not quite on the level of the Bose overall, but I never expected it to be on account of these being earbuds and less than half the price.However, the bass that these earbuds pump out is what really blew me away on first use! The Bose headphones are actually a bit weak on bass, whereas these earbuds provide an impressive thump without distorting or sacrificing clarity across the rest of the frequency range. I'm not saying they have good bass *for ear buds,* I'm saying they pump out the bass, *period.*For reference, this is based on listening to EDM tracks from Pretty Lights and Tycho.COMFORT: They're buds, which are understandably less comfortable for a lot of folks than on-ear or over-ear headphones. But for earbuds, they are quite comfy.The rubber pieces that actually go in your ear are soft and pliable, and they come with FIVE different sizes of those. They fit snugly without feeling like they're stretching my ear canal.I haven't done any running or other major activity with them, but I've never felt at risk of one falling out while just walking around my office.NOISE ISOLATION/CANCELATION: This is actually the first set of noise canceling headphones/earbuds I've ever owned, so I can't compare that functionality to anything else, but I will say this: My office runs white noise machines all the time. When these connect to my phone and the noise cancellation begins, the drone from those machines (which I don't even realize I notice beforehand) suddenly goes completely silent.They also effectively reduce the sound of co-workers talking nearby--not completely, but far more than just putting plugs in my ears would do. (Speaking of noise isolation--just blocking sound by plugging your ears--these do more than any earbuds I've previously owned.)Finally, the different modes of noise cancellation that can be set through the app (more on that shortly) seem reasonably effective, but I haven't put them to the test in a variety of environments yet.BATTERY LIFE: I don't remember this being stated in the description, maybe because it's a given for wireless earbuds nowadays, but the carrying case functions as a power bank for these babies.I don't know how many times the case will charge the earbuds before needing to be recharged itself because I haven't drained it yet (in two weeks of using them every other day for 2-3 hours per day). When that time comes, I think it's neat that the case can charge wirelessly.It also has a microUSB charging port and comes with a cable, the other end of which is standard USB. Nothing comes with wall bricks anymore, but I guess they figure everyone has a few spare ones around by now.TECHNOLOGY: My first thought on being able to access some of the settings/features of these earbuds only through the app was, "UGH, another product-specific app?! *grump*" BUT, this app is remarkably sleek and easy to use. And I say that as someone who works for a software company.Setting the noise cancellation mode and customizing the on-board controls (what happens when you tap the earbuds in different ways during use) is very easy to do. The app also has a sound test feature to help make sure you're wearing the earbuds correctly and have the right size squishy ear piece on them.After initially pairing them with my phone via Bluetooth, the connectivity has worked flawlessly. When I remove them from the case, they connect right away. When I put them back in and close the case, they are disconnected. Every time. No fiddling with settings or having to re-pair.That consistent reliability is very nice, especially for phone calls. If the buds are in my ears, that's where the call comes in. If they're in the case, it comes through the phone speaker. No juggling devices or frantically pressing buttons to sort out where the sound will come out of next. The calls are clear, and the built-in microphones must pick up my voice well enough because I've had no complaints from anyone on the other end.I haven't tested the Bluetooth range on them because my phone is always on me when I'm using them.CONSTRUCTION: Solid build, clear attention to detail. The earbuds pop into the case with a satisfying little snap.The magnet that holds them in is very secure, so even with the case open I'm not worried about them falling out, but not so strong that they're difficult to remove.The case itself is terrifically compact and sturdy. The lid shuts securely, and would clearly protect the earbuds while bouncing around in a purse or backpack all day.SUMMARY: These are great earbuds. For the price, they're amazing earbuds. I know the technology is always advancing, but these do SO MUCH for $70, and they do all of it remarkably well. I've been going out of my way to recommend them to people, which is why I've written this novel of a review. If you've read this far, I certainly hope you've found it helpful. :)
timestamp: Reviewed in the United States November 5, 2022
product_name: Soundcore by Anker Life P3 Noise Cancelling Wireless Bluetooth Earbuds

title: 5.0 out of 5 stars If you're looking for an excellent quality earbud that covers all the bases then you've found it!
author: LYCollins
content: I have tried countless brands and styles of over-the-ear headphones, wired earbuds, wireless earbuds, and all the in between. I need something that works at the gym, on airplanes, while gardening, washing dishes, and driving. The Soundcore Life P3 is the first I've found that can do it ALL.The active noise cancellation is superb, and you can control it via the app or just by touch of the earbuds. I've had other earbuds that say they cancel noise but they don't even come close to these.The range of connection while listening to music, etc. all over my house (inside and outside) is important for me. I don't always bring my phone when I am going around the house, garage, yard, and these stay connected at least 90% of the locations i roam to at the edges of my yards--through closed doors.The quality of connection while in conversation is excellent, no complaints. The water resistance holds up to the IPX5 standard which is just what i need due to sweat & sometimes I (carefully) wash my face with them in.The battery life is excellent. They last a few days without needing to be plugged back into an outlet. The earbuds recharge in 10-15 minutes with the portable charging case. The charging case is even something to rave about! It is small and soft to the touch yet sturdy & durable. I do wish the magnetic closure was a little stronger but that is only because i often drop things & if you drop the case then the earbuds pop out (half the time). But I can honestly say that is my only complaint about these earbuds.I realize I sound like a paid advertisement but I am not - I just LOVE these earbuds. The quality is fantastic, and I think the price is just right: a little expensive but completely worth it.The customer service is the cherry on top! After a couple months of heavy use I had a fluke problem with one earbud and the customer service resolved the issue 100%. They did make me do some extra troubleshooting that was a little painful, and it did resolve the issue for a little while. After that earbud stopped working again I contacted customer service and they could not have been easier or quicker to completely rectify the situation. I am now even more fanatical about this brand.If you're looking for an excellent quality earbud that covers all the bases then you've found it--buy these.It is almost 3 years since I first purchased these & I stand by them 100%. They have taken countless drops, been stepped on a few times, sustained water submersion and still give amazing quality of sound, noise cancellation, and battery life. I have been getting comments about the mic quality on phone calls lately so I will soon replace them as i often use them for work. I will replace them with a new pair of Soundcores!
timestamp: Reviewed in the United States May 21, 2022
product_name: Soundcore by Anker Life P3 Noise Cancelling Wireless Bluetooth Earbuds

title: 4.0 out of 5 stars Unexpectedly satisfied! Sound quality, battery life, accessibility all great.
author: Naglfarslayer
content: UPDATE (3 October 2022):After less than a year of a typical life (no major damage), each earbud has alternated between working and not working over the last month. For the first two weeks, the left earbud was silent, then it suddenly came back to life and the right one went silent within a couple of days and remains so today. Both headphones finally failed during a Zoom meeting this morning and have not yet been resurrected.While these have been excellent headphones, I am disappointed to experience a serious failure like this after LESS THAN ONE YEAR of responsible use and care.These were everything I wanted in new, EXPENSIVE (>$30) headphones.TL;DR: Great sound range (incl. prominent bass), satisfactory battery life (3-4 hours per charge; case gives ~2-3 recharges), and easy accessibility (two-step connection to device; the SoundCore app has a good widget). They are acceptable for voice calls, however they seem to pick up a lot of ambient background noise (papers shuffling, keyboard clicking, etc.), and my callers say the sound quality is better on my iPhone SE 2020 without the headphones, than with them.ONLY COMPLAINTS: very rarely but consistently, the sound will cut out for ~2 seconds before coming back - I believe this occurs when too many other wireless devices are nearby, as it has not happened at all the past 2 hours I've sat here at my work desk after-hours, but it happens every 1-2 minutes in the gym around many people wearing wireless headphones - CONSULT OTHER REVIEWS to see what the consensus is; I'm used to it by now - it's not a surprise and I miss very little in that small 1-2 sec window.NOTE that in-ear headphones naturally block out a lot of sound; 'Transparency Mode' helps to artificially add back in some environmental noise, but it is difficult to reliably hear people talk nearby.OVERALL: I'm very satisfied with the Anker Life P3. The sound quality is very nice (for a normie lol), the battery stays alive for several hours and charges quickly when returned to the case, and it easily pairs with Bluetooth devices.The origin story:I was reluctant to switch to wireless headphones due to the high prices and ease of losing track of them. I had to switch due to upgrading phones (iPhone SE to iPhone SE 2020, can't you tell I'm a cheapskate lol), and exhaustively researched wireless headphones to find a budget-end pair that still boasted good quality.My priorities were something reliable that would survive through long days in the (chemistry) lab, and during workouts (generic 30-45 min weightlifting or cardio). Many reviews recommended the Anker Life P3 as a solid entry on the lower-mid price range, although AirPods tended to remain the gold standard albeit at a notably higher price. Due to the consistent recommendation between reviewers (website and YouTube), I decided to go for it.The Anker Life P3 met my purchasing goals to a T (and I ride Boston's T system now, so I would know!).FIT: The fit feels nice, and the multiple pairs of rubber ear adapters give a chance for all ear sizes to feel comfortable. They don't fall out easily even when I run (both on the treadmill and *real* running), and they feel secure as I walk around. Minor irritation when my ears decide the 'foreign objects' need to leave, although this is rare.SOUND: I've listened to songs I've played for most of my life, and these earphones have brought out parts of the arrangement I have NEVER heard before. The bass is strong, so the full range of sound is there (no 'weak' or 'high' headphone sound here). In my opinion, the sound is powerful but balanced. Equalizers can probably tweak the sound if you prefer a different mix, but these bad boys can sure thump if you want them to!BATTERY: I usually give up before these headphones do. My typically listening sessions go between 30 min to 3 h and I've never had the batteries die on me. They *feel* like they quickly recharge when returned to the case, which provides another 2-3 full charges. The case can be separately recharged using the USB-C to USB-A cable provided; this takes longer, so charge the case overnight and it will keep the headphones charged for the entirety of the next day. Hardcore music marathoners may be less enthused by the battery life, but the Anker Life P3 has a longer lifespan than me!ACCESSIBILITY: I find the Life P3 to be easy to handle, although the initial linking was a bit confusing (and I already forgot how I did it!). When the headphone case is open, the three front lights turn/stay on for a few seconds. Then, the lights ignite in an alternating pattern, which is when the headphones are seeking a Bluetooth partner. On a device that knows the headphones, clicking on 'Soundcore Life P3' on the Bluetooth list will initiate the pairing, and then you're ready to go! To disconnect, you can remove it from the device, turn off the device Bluetooth, or return the headphones to the case and close the case. Unpaired headphones can be immediately paired with another device without having to be returned to the case. Re-cased headphones will immediately pause music/video streaming on the paired device (on Apple products, in my experience). The 'Soundcore' app for phones (haven't seen it for Mac) is very useful, as it provides some EQ's and the Noise Cancellation or Transparency modes. It also provides a widget for quick access to the Cancellation/Transparency/Normal modes for convenient toggling without having to open the app.Note: The headphone stems have two or three swipe features. I use these sparingly and have not investigated them further. One gesture skips to the next audio (song skip or 'next YouTube video in queue') which is convenient when desired; sometimes it takes me several attempts to gesture in a way the headphones will recognize, but more practice will likely help that.OTHER: As with all in-ear headphones, these naturally block a good 70% of external noise, and loud music will take out another 10-15% on top of that. It is near-impossible to hear people speaking to me with these headphones in; at most I get an inaudible, deep rumble that tells me someone is trying to speak to me. This is fine if you're prepared for it, but it is inconvenient to remove one headphone every time someone speaks to me - consider your intended use and how common this will be for you. The noise cancellation works very well, IMO, as only minor vibrations and deep sounds come through; I've experienced no intelligible talking in the background with that feature on, and bus/subway rides only have a deep hum characteristic of public transportation.ONE COMPLAINT: As mentioned in the TL;DR above, the sound does cut out for 1-2 seconds rarely, although this becomes more common in crowded ares with a higher density of wireless headphones. My hypothesis is that too much Bluetooth air traffic makes it difficult to stay connected to the signal, but I have no idea. This has only been a major issue in the gym, where the phenomenon seems frequent and consistent; I've only taken these to the gym two or three times, though. Check other reviews!OVERALL: I am quite satisfied with these headphones. $70 for exactly what I wanted? YES! When I inevitably drop one of the headphones down a storm drain, I will definitely look for another pair of Anker Life P3, or consider their other similar products.

title: 5.0 out of 5 stars Solid earbuds - must buy
author: Matt W
content: Listen, for the price point, you likely wonâ€™t get better overall earbuds. Seriously.Are these as good as Apple AirPods or the newest Sony earbuds? No, but theyâ€™re also 75% cheaper.The good:* Battery life - 6-8 hours (over 24hrs with case)* Soundcore app - lots of customization and built in natural sounds to help you relax, focus, or sleep. Some sounds it offers are wind, rain, thunder, ocean, trains, etc. it very effective and a genius idea.* price point - you wonâ€™t find better earbuds at a better price than this. timestamp: Reviewed in the United States February 4, 2024
product_name: Soundcore by Anker Life P3 Noise Cancelling Wireless Bluetooth Earbuds

title: 5.0 out of 5 stars These buds are part of my life now.
author: Trucker Frank
content: I absolutely love these ear buds!Comfort:I've never been a fan of ear buds in general because they've always hurt my ears but these don't. They are very comfortable and I can actually wear them for over an hour without them bothering me.Sound:The sound out of these little things is awesome! Loud, clear and full sound. Great bass which surprised me because I didn't expect it. Nice clear highs that don't sound like tin.Noise Cancelling:I've been using these in very noisy environments and they do extremely well. I work in trucking and my favorite place to use these is in the yard truck at the terminal while moving trailers around. It's an old beat up terminal tractor that just makes a ton of noise and clanks, bangs, shakes, and in general just a loud annoying place to be. These ear buds bring all that noise to a slight hum. With the music at half volume you barely hear the noise at all. Also did an excellent job at keeping things quiet while running the snow blower on my driveway.Transparency Mode:This feature works as expected. Not sure what else to say about it really lol. If I keep the music at a quarter volume I can hold a conversation with people even in a warehouse environment without feeling like I have to shout over the music or guess what they're trying to tell me. They also have a vocal mode in the software which actually makes some voices clearer when the person is at a distance and standing next to a noisy truck.Phone calls:They sound great and the caller can hear me perfectly too! I was blown away by this because going back to the terminal tractor I was talking about in the noise cancelling part of this review it's noisy... But the caller and I can clearly hold a conversation and it sounds great on both sides of the call. On a side note, the call sounds and goes smoothly even with a winter beeny hat over them WHILE DRIVING that insanely noisy truck!Battery life:The battery life has been great for my use case. I don't really wear them for very long in one shot like other people might. But, I've never had them go low on me and I've been on the same charge for the past 3 weeks with using them about 2 to 3 hours a day 5 days out of the week and I pretty much exclusively use noise cancelling or transparency modes. With that in mind when I put them back in the case I still get the 3 lights for state of charge.The Case:THANK YOU ANKER for pretty much having USB-C on everything you guys make and not putting Micro B on the lower cost products! Seriously, I really appreciate that. The case itself is great too. The ear buds snap in nice and easy when putting them away without fumbling. The shape of it feels good in my inside coat pocket which I know is subjective but I can say it's definitely not an annoying thing to carry. The cover is a cover lol. It closes nice, doesn't flop open and doesn't feel flimsy. The 3 lights show battery state of charge and light up for bud engagement confirmation when placing a bud in the case which is nice.Bluetooth:Works fantastic as you'd expect out of a device these days. Paired instantly with my phone on the first try. Doesn't cut out or cause any fuss and it's not laggy.Cons:I really haven't found any. But if I really had to be picky... I wish the volume control was a swipe gesture instead of a tap. It would be nice if they told you battery percentage when you turn the buds on. And I wish I had a case for the case, which may sound silly but a clamshell zipper case would be nice to have just to keep them extra safe. Honestly, I love these things so much that I'd probably cry if anything happened to them lol.

title: 5.0 out of 5 stars First impressions. Very good for the price, with a couple of minor bugs.
author: LCB
content: I wanted earbuds that offered good quality for classical music at a decent price. After checking online reviews I ordered these.Pros:1. Sound: Sound quality is quite well balanced. The app for these buds includes an equalizer that allows you to types of music (jazz, classical, electronic, etc., etc., etc...). The equalizer also has a custom feature that allows you to customize your sound.2. App: The app is very intuitive, and in addition to the equalizer, includes controls for ambient sound (noise cancellation), gaming mode, tip fit test, etc.. It also shows you how to set up the buds right out of the box. and allows you to customize the tap settings, etc. I haven't used it for phone calls, but some reviewers say they work well.3. Charging: You can use a USB cable or a wireless charging pad to charge it.Cons:1. User manual: The included manual is useless. It's printed in tiny light blue font on white (Why? Why? Oh Why?). I downloaded the pdf version of the manual and had to blow it up to read it.The good news is that you can ditch the manual and use the app, which explains everything you need.2. Ear Tips: It includes several size ear-tips, but as other reviewers noted, they don't do a good job of securing the buds. Fortunately I had a set of "LUDOS Comfy Earbuds Replacement Memory Foam Ear Tips" (Available on Amazon). These come in several sizes and colors including dayglow (makes finding the buds easier). They work perfectly.3. Noise cancellation: The app allows you to select different cancellation modes. Although noise-cancellation is not perfect, it's good for most environments.Final notes: These are not on a league with $200.00 plus earbuds, but if you are on a budget, you get a lot of bang for the buck at $70.00.

content: About a year with my Life P3 and the left earbud gave up the ghost. Looking back at the last few weeks I think there were signs that I wrote off as little glitches. Things like the mic not working until I reconnected and the audio balance between left and right earbuds being very noticeable.Then last week the left ear just stopped working. I did all the things suggested on the site (cleaning the connections with rubbing alcohol, delete and resetup connection, making sure itâ€™s fully charged, etc etc etc.) but no luck.Poking around the Soundcore site I see that the earbuds are covered under an 18 month warranty so a few hours after filling out their online form I receive the first of 3 emails advising that I do all the things I did already to see if that would get the earbud to work. As annoying as that is, I get they need to make sure customers are putting in the effort.I respond back letting them know I did each of the troubleshooting suggestions but apparently I wasnâ€™t clear enough about the rubbing alcohol cleaning because I received the 2nd of my 3 emails stating I need to make sure the connecting points are cleaned which I responded back more carefully this time, making sure to include keywords so the bots know I did my part. The following day I get the 3rd and final email apologizing for the issue and telling me that I should expect a new pair of replacement buds to come out to me in about a week's time.I took that turnaround time with a grain of salt and assumed I would probably see it in a month since I wasnâ€™t sure where it was coming from and how quickly they would have it in a box.2 days later, I come home and thereâ€™s a box at my door. just 2 days and I have my new earbuds. I am so impressed by their turnaround that Iâ€™m willing to overlook the robo emails I had to go through before getting to this part.I am really impressed by their customer service and have another reason to want to continue to be an Anker customer.
timestamp: Reviewed in the United States June 8, 2024
product_name: Soundcore by Anker Life P3 Noise Cancelling Wireless Bluetooth Earbuds

title: 5.0 out of 5 stars Incredible Value
author: jdan318
content: About 2 years ago I bought a pair of these, but recently lost them. I thought of getting a more expensive pair to replace them, but decided these did well enough before. I wouldn't call myself an audiophile, but I am a musician, often mix live sound, and have owned many different pairs of decent open-backed and IEM headphones over the years, so I have some experience with sound quality.The sound quality on this new pair seems near identical to the old ones, which is good for music and videos, but both the battery and noise cancelation is noticeably improved on this newer pair. I would have been happy with an identical product, but the improvements make me very glad I didn't spend money on more expensive wireless earbuds, as these are more than decent, they are good, and for the money I dare say they are great.Update: Went on my first flight, so can give a more comprehensive review on the noise canceling. For cars I've been a passenger in, it eliminates road noise to the point I can't hear it. For a 737 when I'm in a window seat right behind the engine, it eliminates a lot of noise, but it certainly is still there. Still, turning it off then on again showcased that it still was bringing it down a ton, but these are not complete elimination (like I've read the Bose are).Still, while these are great at eliminating road, engine, and wind noise, what they do almost nothing for is voices. They do fit flush in my ear and create a seal, which does an okay job of bringing down talking and crying, but I still clearly heard babies crying during the flights. In the airport terminal, the indoor mode did lower the din of many people talking, but anything remotely close where you could listen to what they are saying still comes through. It does something, and for the price still is fine, but don't expect anything close to silence when surrounded by people talking.

title: 5.0 out of 5 stars So happy with these!
author: Dan
content: I have a Samsung Galaxy A14 and bought thr Galaxy Pro 2 earbuds for $115, but no matter what I did, I couldn't bring out mid- and high-frequency in the mix, it was dominated by bass. They sound great and I can clearly hear the detail in the mids and highs. Just got them, so don't know yet about battery life, ANR, etc., but I got them for the sound.I had a lot of trouble pairing them, but it turns out Bluetooth was trying to recognize my old pair of Anker Soundcore earbuds, which showed up on my Bluetooth scan, and getting confused. I went to Bluetooth settings and "forgot" the older earbuds, rebooted everything including the phone, earbuds, Bluetooth, and Soundcore app, and the new earbuds showed up on my Bluetooth scan and I was able to connect easily. There is info online on how to "forget" and "unforget" Bluetooth connections.

title: 4.0 out of 5 stars Great for Calls; Lacking 2 Features
author: silverado98_nighthawk84
content: This is now my third pair of earbuds. Comparing this to my previous ones (Earfun Air Pro 3, Earfun Air Pro), these Soundcore Life P3 knock it out of the park when it comes to background noise isolation in calls. Absolute night and day difference. I did a test in a noisy room (fan/air noise from a large HVAC unit) and these were so much clearer. The background noise was almost non-existent. I bought these primarily based on reviews of excellent call quality, and so far that has been true. I'll be testing more with phone calls as time goes on. As far as sound goes when listening to music, the quality seems top-notch, especially for the price point (I was able to snag these on sale). Personal preference, but I like the Soundcore Signature equalizer setting. It also has a BassUp option that I like as well. Upon opening the case, they pair very quickly with my phone.So far, my only dislikes/gripes with these are: 1) lack of ear/proximity detection and 2) lack of multi-device (multipoint) connection. With today's bluetooth technology, I don't understand why the multi-device connection is missing. My Earfun Air Pro has it and I didn't pay any more for them than I did these. (Earfun Air Pro 3 also lack this feature.) I can and will live without the ear detection, but having to constantly disconnect and reconnect between my phone and computer is going to be an annoyance more than anything. Had these Soundcore Life P3 included this, I would have given them five stars, even without the ear detection.

title: 4.0 out of 5 stars Would and Have Recommended
author: Taylar Karnes
content: I work in a university lab space where I use these headphones for about 50 hours every single week. I'm also very clumsy, resulting in these headphones experiencing many hip-height drops to concrete floors. Despite this, they have lasted me much longer than any other earbud has to date at 20 months of constant use and abuse - and they are only giving out in the sense that the dwindled battery life (expected of rechargeable batteries vs. replaceable batteries) is becoming a nuisance when I can't constantly switch them in the lab. Good sound quality and noise canceling with customizing available through the manufactures app. Until recently, I have been getting 8-9 hours of battery life per earbud and only changing the case once per week. I have occasionally struggled with bluetooth connectivity not recognizing the device, though I suspect this is linked to drops and repairing the device solves the problem quickly. Fit of the in ear buds is good, though not perfect and occasionally require adjusting or result in slipping.Ultimately, I would and have recommended these to coworkers and friends, and will be buying a new pair to refresh battery longevity for personal convenience.

title: 5.0 out of 5 stars Amazing bass and great ANC
author: Andrew
content: Itâ€™s amazing how much quality and great features youâ€™re getting at this price point. I honestly didnâ€™t know what to expect, since Iâ€™m used to buying much more expensive gear, so I wasnâ€™t expecting much. I gotta say, I was pleasantly surprised! They sound GREAT, extra, full range, deep bass, but the rest of the frequency range sounds good. Definitely not muddy or overbearing, I listened to rock as well as bass heavy electronic tracks and all sounded great.Comfort:Comfort for me is the #1 thing when it comes to earbuds or headphones. It doesnâ€™t matter how good they sound or how good the ANC or features are if theyâ€™re not comfortable! These fit the bill nicely. I had never worn stem style earbuds before, but it doesnâ€™t really make a noticeable difference to your comfort anyway, you canâ€™t feel the stem. These are light and donâ€™t apply pressure to any area on my ear that would otherwise lead to discomfort (like most of the other earbuds in the market that are unnecessarily large, like the new Sony WF-1000XM4). I can wear these for hours with no discomfort whatsoever, so we got a winner here.ANC: The ANC on these is a bit different than what Iâ€™m used to, as Iâ€™ve never owned earbuds with ANC, just cans like my beloved Bose QC35â€™s and my JBL Tour One, of which the Bose obviously is the king. Well, when compared to my Bose, these Life P3â€™s do a pretty good job of muffling the heavy, industrial fan I have in my room, and in some cases blocking out different frequencies better than the Bose. The fan just sounds different. Maybe it's not as quiet as with the Bose but the pitch it gets on these is very subdued. (I have a VERY loud fan in my room on purpose so as to have a very loud white noise that I can sleep to while drowning out the rest of the outside noises that wake me otherwise). The thing about the ANC on these earbuds is that it has 3 modes, transit, indoor and outdoor. I found indoor to be the best for me personally around the house, it brought a very impressive level of attenuation. I could still clearly hear my dogs barking but all the other, more constant noises went VERY silent. In some cases it feels more silent than the Bose cans do, and those are among the best ANC performers on the market. Donâ€™t get me wrong, the Bose are still kings in that regard, but it does by no means put these buds to shame, they stand up surprisingly well. I wish there was an option for selecting â€œmaximumâ€ ANC where it would mix the 3 options, because while standing next to my fan, I went through all 3 and they each blocked a different frequency range from the fan and changed its pitch and perceived loudness. Iâ€™m sure theyâ€™re capable of consolidating all 3 and bringing even more impressive ANC but I suspect they donâ€™t do this in order to not hurt their flagship. Just my guess but regardless, the ANC performance in these buds is nothing to scoff at and I am actually very happy with and impressed by them in that regard. Transparency mode on these is also very good, you donâ€™t have to take your buds out in order to have a conversation or be aware of your surroundings. I have mine set to long press to switch between ANC on and Ambient aware on. Which brings me to the next plus, the touch controls on these earbuds is actually decent, unlike my JBL Tour One where adjusting my headset often times results in activating the touch controls unintentionally. That doesnâ€™t happen with these buds.Find my buds:This has a feature where it makes your buds make a loud noise so you can find them. Pretty neat if you ask me, Iâ€™m thinking of getting a pair of these for my mother, since sheâ€™s constantly losing everything.In conclusion:Iâ€™m very happy with my purchase, I have included many pictures so you can see what you get when you buy these and what it all looks like. I would definitely recommend these to anyone, for the money, they canâ€™t be beat and even if they were more expensive, Iâ€™m sure most would be happy with them.

title: 2.0 out of 5 stars Used to recommend, Now I don't :(
author: Zak Awry
content: UPDATE 09/02/21: Although I do still love them I can't recommend them anymore for the following reasons:1. I've found issues with disconnecting them from my phones bluetooth then trying to reconnect them to my computer bluetooth it just tells me it can't connect to the P3's. It's a MAJOR pain to disconnect them from your phone, put them back in their case and close it, open it back up and take them out and disconnect them again from my phone when they automatically reconnect to the last device and finally be able to connect to my computer. I don't know if that's the norm? Or if it's something I'm doing but that's been my experience trying to switch between two devices. Not always, but frequently enough to be a problem.2. Along the lines with connectivity issues, I've also had recent problems where they were connected to my phone and I put them in their case for a length of time (anywhere from 15 mins to an hour) and I grab them out of the case walking out the door to start walking expecting that they'll automatically connected like usual but for some reason they don't/wont reconnect for seemingly no reason. The first time it happened I chalked it up to user error but after a 3rd or 4th time I'm starting to suspect it's product. It's easy to reset them with the case but I don't take the case on walks with me so can be SUPER annoying and unusable for the duration of your walk/activity.3. Today after resetting the head phones I connected them to my computer to listen to music while my phone did a system update. I've frequently had it connected to my computer in the past for Zoom calls and listening to music and videos, etc. Normally when connected to the computer I have the same sound quality I do when connected to my phone, however, today for the first time, after connecting it to my computer the sound quality was TERRIBLE. And I don't mean just kind of bad I mean it sounds like a low quality tape recording from the radio coming out of a blown phone speaker in a bowl (When using a streaming service like Spotify or YouTube). I'm SUPER disappointed in them. I don't know if they did an update that f-ed them all up or what but yikes. Due to the recent issue's I've experienced I've reduced my original 5 star rating down to a 2 star. :( Hopefully their next headphone release will be way better. Maybe the Liberty Air Pro 2's are better?I'm new to the Soundcore Brand but after paying $40 dollars for one of there older earbuds and being blown away I figured I'd pay a little more and try a higher quality ear bud from them and....just wow. These are far better than I was expecting. I might be a little easier satisfied than someone who classifies themselves as an 'audiophile' or someone who needs head phones for music production reasons and although the noise cancelling isn't quite as good as my over the ear Sony WH-1000XM4 but the Life P3's are $270 LESS and they're actually pretty darn close. The P3's have a great fit for your ears, I can do yoga while wearing them and they don't fall out. The App is a very nice touch. Nothing worse than trying to figure out what you're doing pushing and holding buttons like on the Life A1's but not knowing what equalizer you're on. Incredible sound and base and they get SUPER LOUD.Pros:~The App - Gives you a battery life indicator for each head phone, Gives you access to Ambient Sound, Gaming Mode, Equalizer, Controls, Superior sleep sounds, and Tip Fit Test * Gives you 3 ambient sound options Noise Cancellation, Transparency mode, and normal mode. 3 options for noise cancellation - transport, indoor, and outdoor. * Gaming mode - you can turn on to reduce the latency while gaming or watching videos. * Equalizer - gives you the option to custom tune your earbuds or using one of their 21 preset ones. * Controls - lets you customize the touch response on the ear buds to do the controls that you want the most. * Superior Sleep gives you access to 11 ambient sounds to help you fall asleep (although, you're a champion if you can fall asleep with these or any other ear buds in.) * Tip Fit Test - Tests the Tip seal on the head phones to make sure you're getting the most out of your ear buds.~ Tip Selection - Like all of Soundcore ear buds a huge selection of ear tip pieces so you can get a comfortable fit.~ Wireless charging case~ Noise Cancellation - is it the best? Probably not. Will it block out a lot of the noise? Absolutely. I used to have to close my office door every day at work when coworkers would start talking, now my doors wide open and I can't hear any of them.~ Comfort - I was worried that with my ears and everything that they might stick out too far but they sit comfortably inside of my ear and don't stick out far at all. Looks like I have Air pods in.~ So many color options.Cons: There aren't many that I can find.~ No bluetooth Multipoint (Being able to connect to more than one bluetooth at a time.) This is the biggest con for me. (Don't believe any of the Soundcore ear buds have this yet, but may be wrong.)~ No in ear detection when you remove an ear bud to pause music.~ No HearID in the app - I believe that's because that's a Liberty series feature, so I guess it makes sense it's not included.If you're trying to decide between the Liberty Air 2 Pro or the Life P3's I can't see much of a difference between them other than the HearID test. If you have extra money to burn or the HearID is a super important feature you want, I'd honestly stick with the Life P3's and save $50 bucks.I'm hoping on Soundcores next ear bud release will include the in ear detection as well as the multipoint bluetooth connection (Hopefully on the liberty series so I can try the HearID as well).

Sounds great, phone calls were very clear on both ends and they never fell out or moved and I move around quite a bit. I used $300 JBLs that turned out to be crap so I just threw those away after using these. The only arguably bad thing I have to say is that you don't have a "one touch" operation when you only have one of them in your ear. You only have the "double touch" or "2sec hold" option but that definitely doesn't break it for me, especially for the price.
timestamp: Reviewed in the United States June 13, 2024
product_name: Soundcore by Anker Life P3 Noise Cancelling Wireless Bluetooth Earbuds

title: 4.0 out of 5 stars Updated to 4 Stars Based on Customer Service/Fixes for several issues
author: James
content: Leaving my original review below but changing my review to 4 stars based on the customer service. I reached out to Anker about my issues below and their CSR was very responsive. She walked me through a number of steps and when resets, etc. did not fix the connection problems, she gave me a RMA and shipped me a new unit as well as some foam eartips. The foam tips did WONDERS. I am surprised that they do not include them as an option in the box from the get go (maybe people like me are a very small minority) but they worked really well in keeping the buds in place. They will still come out in extended use (still waiting on a spirit x version of these) but I definitely don't have the same fear that they will fall out at an inopportune time. I still have a few connection issues from time to time and the lack of physical buttons can often be rage inducing so I'm not giving these 5 stars but they are a really good value for the money and from a company that stands behind their product.Original review below:Anker has provided so much value to me over the years (to date, I've bought the soundcore life 2, life q20, spirit X, curve, and an untold amount of cables :D) and I want to love these earbuds so much. There's so much promise and so many features but the sum of it all falls short for me.First off, they look great - as soon as I bought them (my first set of wireless earbuds), people in my office were asking what they were because they looked really sharp. When I am sitting down at my desk and have both of these in, they are really good at blocking out exterior noise which is why I bought them (I work in a refashioned warehouse and the HVAC system and the industrial refrigerators we have create a ton of looping, irritating noise). The ANC is pretty solid for my needs and the sound quality for the podcasts I listen to seems really good.However, the problems arise when I am not using them in that ideal scenario (seated, both buds in). When I have one bud in, the touch controls don't seem to work as well and I have to try a few times for the command to register, if it does at all. This might be a minor quibble as I'm not sure how many people are going into "mono" mode but since it is most of my day, it can make the headphones borderline unusable for me. In the same vein, I do like the app (Android) but I hate the widget - whenever I flip to it to switch the hearing modes, it never says the buds are connected...even though they are in my ear and playing music. It defeats the purpose of using a widget because I then have to unlock my phone and do it through the app. Now, I wouldn't have to do it through the app ... if the touch controls worked properly when I had one bud in. It's a cycle of frustration!Finally, the biggest problem for me is that the buds simply do not stay in all the time. especially when I am walking. I have tried several of the covers that they provided in the box and while I get a good seal for listening, I can feel the bud start to slip out of my ear as I am walking. I start panicking that it's going to fall and slam on the stamped concrete floors of the office and I'm going to be out the money I paid for these. If Anker made a spirit X version of these that hooked above the ear, that might be a better choice for me. For now, because of the above frustrations, these have been relegated to just at home use for my wife and I when we are not being active and can have both buds in.
timestamp: Reviewed in the United States July 17, 2021
product_name: Soundcore by Anker Life P3 Noise Cancelling Wireless Bluetooth Earbuds

title: 5.0 out of 5 stars Very impressive buds for the price
author: H. Fox
content: I'm nothing close to being an audiophile, but I use earbuds and headphones of several different brands a lot, in and out of the house. As a 65+ senior with a mild but annoying tinnitus problem, I use my AirPods Pro every time I watch TV at home because, without them, it's very difficult to catch all of the dialogue of almost every program I watch. They sync with my LG TV very well so I don't have to adjust TV settings for video/audio syncing.But this is a review of the Soundcore by Anker Life P3 Noise Cancelling Earbuds, so why am I talking up the AirPods Pro? Simple. They make for a great comparison. I've owned earlier versions of the Anker Soundcore non-ANC buds that were less expensive, and it showed in their performance. But, I gotta say, the P3 ANCs are way, way better. I don't fly a lot, but recently, on some very long flights from Florida to western Canada, the P3s really shined. The constant noise level in most airliners is terrible and completely wears me out even after short flights. I was skeptical about using earbuds instead of headphones, but I literally couldn't believe my ears when I popped the P3s in and was instantly transformed by the quiet! Their noise canceling performance might not be the very best, but I've tried other brands including Sony, Sennheiser and Bowers-Wilkins and the P3s are truly nearly as good - including my AirPods Pro, which are my all-time favorites for both overall sound quality and ANC. The shocker, of course, is that the P3s are a fraction of the cost.To my problematic ears the sound quality of the P3s isn't quite there, but they are way more than just satisfactory. I would have given them four-and-a-half stars for that aspect, but Amazon won't let me. All around, the P3s are just plain awesome, and at their price point, they're amazing. Oh, and by the way, they work very well with my LG TV also. If I couldn't, or didn't want to, afford the AirPods Pro, the P3s would make me very happy as an alternative.Now for one quibble. The P3s charging case is just plain terrible. Not because they don't protect the buds or charge them properly, but because, in my experience, they're constantly popping open and dropping the P3s at the worst possible moments. The case is SO easy to accidently pop open, that if dropped a mere few inches onto a firm surface, mine would flop open and invariably the earbuds would just fall out. This made for some especially exciting moments on said airline trip to Canada. I nearly lost the P3s several times when they'd fall out of a pocket, or my backpack, and the case would pop open and scatter the buds in different directions. Just try finding two black earbuds on black carpet under your airline seat a couple times - not a pleasant experience. Heads up, Anker! I love a lot of your products, but you could do seriously better designing a case for such great earbuds.

title: 4.0 out of 5 stars Great for price, very strong bass (maybe too strong)
author: eqrweqe
content: I revisited these after my Sony WF-1000XM4's started experiencing battery issues and the company wouldn't replace them.Putting them in is still a trick I'm learning to master. I still don't quite get the "lock" movement, but once they're in they stay in about as well as any other bud.For the price, the sound quality is essentially the same as the XM4's. Both earbuds needed some fussing with the EQ to get the best profile. The major difference is that while Sony lets you control the bass boost, this one goes full throttle. I had to heavily boost all the other frequencies in the EQ while reducing the lower frequencies to near zero (see screenshot for my recommendation) just to get it to a level I would consider acceptable. Some will like how ungodly strong it is, others will not.Noise canceling seems to be about on par with Sony, but the ambient sound is definitely much worse. The XM4's were clear as day whereas these still sound quite muffled. But the XM4's are a few bennies whereas this is 60 bucks, so you can't really complain too much.Touch controls are responsive, though you might get some accidental presses here and there. The only thing I wish these had was a sensor to automatically pause when you take the earbuds out, but I think I'll live.Bottom line, for 60 bucks these are really good earbuds that can compete with the best, with a few caveats here and there.

title: 4.0 out of 5 stars Good value for price - with a catch
author: StephenH
content: Briefly, I find these earbuds well worth the price and recommend them. My review is not a comparison of the product to others but the value of my purchase. * Noise cancellation is so-so overall. It's not "true" noise cancellation but rather smooths out ambient sounds. For example, the outdoor setting is reasonable for reducing wind noise but does not eliminate it. However, I do not find stark differences between the settings. The app has been updated since my purchase a couple months ago, and my initial experience with noise reduction was better before the update(s). Users can hope for Anker to do more tweaking to improve this feature.* Fit and finish is good. The case seems sturdy and would probably easily withstand a few drops. I like the tip selection and customizing them did improve my experience, although not as dramatically as perhaps advertised. I have slept with these earbuds with no negative consequence. The tap response is satisfactory although requiring something of a firm touch - some users may appreciate this while others might prefer a lighter touch.* The app is easy to navigate and the preset equalizer settings are numerous. The various settings are unique and have a qualitative impact on sound. This is not a situation where the user changes a setting and struggles to hear the difference. I have had no problem with the buds synching with my device or with each other (e.g., one earbud works but the other does not).* Sound quality is good and provides a good range of tones. I am a bit skeptical of the "big bass," but again the setting does have an impact on sound. An audiophile should probably look elsewhere but sound quality will well satisfy most users.* The range - the distance between my device and the earbuds - is good. I am fortunate to live in a larger than average home and do not lose connection unless I am on the opposite end of the house from my device.* I have not used the wireless charging but have no reason to doubt the function. Otherwise, the battery appears to have a long-life; I have yet to experience running out of charge either with the earbuds themselves or with the case. I typically use these a few hours a day and charge the case every few weeks.* I reserve my opinion about using these earbuds on a phone call because I haven't taken a call. However, I have noticed that when my phone rings, the ringtone sounds tinny. This doesn't bode well for calls, although voices - such as audiobooks and podcasts - have a good sound.After two months of use, I recommend these earbuds and would likely buy them again (e.g., should I lose this pair). However, I paid $20 less than the current list price - a $60 purchase - and found it a very good deal. At $80, a consumer might shop a little more and possibly consider their device (Apple v. Android) and preference for better noise cancellation. Nonetheless, the average listener will be satisfied with the purchase even at the higher price point.
timestamp: Reviewed in the United States January 5, 2022
product_name: Soundcore by Anker Life P3 Noise Cancelling Wireless Bluetooth Earbuds

title: 4.0 out of 5 stars Incredible base, great noise cancellation, needs mute function
author: Scoobi_FreeBSD
content: These are my 1st attempt at using an ear bud-style audio device since trying the wired bluetooth kind probably 5 years ago; those had an ear hook wrapped around my ear to hold them in. Other ear buds I've tried would not stay in my ears, so I've been using over-the-ear headphones.These ear buds fit my ears pretty well; the initial rubber cups that go into the ear seemed to fit pretty well; I tried 1 size up and 1 size down, actually went with 1 size up on the left ear. The buds work themselves out of my ears when I'm chewing (not sure if that's a common problem), but otherwise they stay in place fairly well when sitting at my desk (haven't tried them at the gym yet...guess I'll have to start going again).I read the reviews on the great bass response of these buds, they're all true! I was amazed at how realistic the bass was when listening to TV shows (e.g. the scene transition sound in The Big Bang Theory). Noise cancellation is also excellent; when I turn on noise cancellation with the TV on, it's almost like someone hit the mute button (of course it's not perfect and I can still hear the TV). Noise cancellation can be customized using the downloadable mobile app to cancel specific frequencies, or to pass through voice frequencies. Battery life is excellent, lasting at least 5 hours before the buds notify me with "battery low" every 5 minutes. One bud will konk out first and the other one several minutes later. I can use the buds with a fully-charged case for several days on a single case charge, using them a few (~2-4) hours per day. Microphones are good quality; I have not had any complaints from people I've been on calls with.The buds are controlled via capacitive touch actions on the main outer body of each bud. There are 3 actions one can perform on each bud - single tap, double tap and long press. Each action can be mapped to one of a number of actions - volume up, volume down, cycle through noise cancellation modes, initiate voice assistant (e.g. Alexa or Google Home), next track, previous track, play/pause. Single tap cannot do voice assistant, as of firmware version 02.61.The case is small, about the size of a plum. I've dropped the case with the ear buds in it a couple times, no noticeable damage, but the ear buds will fly everywhere.My only complaint is with the app and a missing "mute" function which can silence all audio from a paired Bluetooth device so I can hear what someone is saying. The app is reasonably user-friendly, and you essentially need it to change noise cancellation mode between all of the available modes (there's 6). Tap actions can only move you between the 3 categories - normal (off), transparency (allow certain frequencies) and noise cancellation. It would be nice if they added a mute/unmute tap action which turns off the audio I'm listening to.

title: 4.0 out of 5 stars Good Deal for The Money.
author: Woody D.
content: I am a former live sound engineer. To me sound quality is the number one concern. My last two sets of buds were actually sold as in ear monitors for professional musicians. One set were wired Sony's and the other Advanced AD3 wireless with a wire between the buds. Both had excellent sound quality. Since I have not had individual buds before and was afraid of losing one, I decided not to break the bank with my first pair. High end buds go for north of $200. I bought the P3s after doing quite a bit of research.When they arrived they were pretty easy to set up. The app you use with them is pretty simple. It includes a customizable EQ so you can tailor the sound to your liking. I use a "dog eared" setting boosting the bass and treble while leaving the midrange flat. The sound is really quite good.I would call the noise cancelling decent but not great. Of course in my opinion the only way you get great cancelling is with full headphones. You have a choice of different NC settings. I find the "indoor" setting works the best at the gym to somewhat drown out the music they are playing. I have not tried them on an airplane yet. As I mentioned I was afraid of losing a bud....so much that I leave them in until I get home and dump them in the charging case. When I leave the gym I just switch to the "Ambient" sound mode and I can hear the world around me pretty well. The buds work very well for phone calls. My wife says my voice sounds perfect when she calls.The controls on the buds for changing volume or tracks work ok, but are not perfect. At time I find myself just reaching for my phone to change track or adjust volume. That may be more about my gnarly fingers than the buds.I am still trying to get the pairing routine worked out. I have them paired with my phone, tablet and Peloton. I know they are supposed to pair automatically to the primary device, but I find I need to put them into pairing mode most of the time. Once paired they are rock solid....solid as in I left my phone on a machine at the gym, went to the other side of the building and they still worked.The buds fit well in my ears. I don't run, but a sweaty in the saddle, out of the saddle Peloton HIIT ride does not pop them out.The battery life seems good, but honestly I do not wear them more than a couple of hours and the rest of the time they live in their charging case.I would recommend these buds for people who want a pair of bud with good sound and don't want to break the bank to get it. They also look pretty cool.
timestamp: Reviewed in the United States April 1, 2022
product_name: Soundcore by Anker Life P3 Noise Cancelling Wireless Bluetooth Earbuds

title: 4.0 out of 5 stars Quality and Comfort for Under $100
author: E. J.
content: EDIT: 7/31/21. I really want to love these earbuds, but the audio keeps cutting out consistently when I use them. Iâ€™ve unpaired them from my phone several times, and deleted the device from my phone with no improvement. I still enjoy these earbuds, but I assume they are a faulty set.*Original Review*Iâ€™ve used these earbuds for almost 2 weeks and hereâ€™s my thoughts:1: Great value for the price.I preordered my pair and got a early bird discount code in my email for 20% off the day they launched. I paid around $65 when I purchased them, tax included.2: Very comfortable.These earbuds have a similar fit to AirPods Pro in the way they nestle on the outer edge of the ear canal. I wear the largest size ear tips and they fit securely. They donâ€™t â€œplugâ€ your ears, but thereâ€™s a slight suction to keep them secure with minimal pressure.3: Sound quality is top tier under $100. Compared to AirPods Pro, thereâ€™s richer bass and clarity in my opinion. I achieved this by fiddling with the EQ on the Soundcore app. The default settings are fine, but the sound profile is much more nuanced and not as compressed when you customize it for your taste. I set mine to the R&B preset and customized it.4: Excellent battery life.On my days off I always have my earbuds in listening to YouTube, Apple Music, etc., and they exceeded my expectations. I only had to recharge once every 2-3 days in the time Iâ€™ve had them. The case is fairly quick to charge and the earbuds themselves recharge fast after using them throughout the day.5: Noise cancellation is decent.The noise cancellation is detectable and can be very useful in certain environments, but donâ€™t expect complete silence while using it. The different modes are useful, but I prefer to use the indoor mode the most. I estimate about a 50-60% noise reduction when I listen to my fridge running while using the noise cancellation.6: Instant pairing.When I get ready to use the earbuds, they pair with my phone before I get to put them in my ears. The pairing and connection range is very strong and consistent.I have some small criticisms too, starting with the audio playback.1: Audio can randomly go mute while playing media for 1-2 seconds at random times throughout the day. It happens maybe 3-5 times a day and isnâ€™t intrusive, but can get annoying while you watch videos. I understand this is a new product and hopefully this will get fixed with firmware updates.2: Touch controls can be finicky (operator error)Thereâ€™s a little learning curve to double tap consistently so the earbuds can recognize it. You have to tap near the very top of the earbud stem or it wonâ€™t work. It puts pressure into your ear when you tap and the video or music may not recognize it every time.All things considered, these earbuds are a great choice for anyone balling on a budget that wants quality and comfort for under $100.

title: 4.0 out of 5 stars Great pair of PC headsets.
author: jesus
content: So I did try to return these. Overall the sound quality is amazing and the sound isolation is not bad. While I'm used to airpods pro 2 and airpods max type of isolation. These are not bad.I mainly bought this as a replacement for my airpods pro 1 generations. As I lost them and find my was not picking up an active trace. I also use both android and iPhone so I wanted a device that essentially runs on both platforms.The case is good with strong magents to hold the ear pieces in. Good sound quality that I think most will enjoy and the features are not too bad.The only issue I had is when I was using them on my phone there was a type of glitch where sound just goes to 100% and I have to click the volume to go back to where it was. What I Mean by this is that let's say I'm watching a video or listen to music at 30% volume. Out of nowhere the audio sounds like it went to 100% which in turn hurts my ears. I then scramble to lower the volume but with one click it goes back to normal. So it wasn't really cranked up to 100% but audio did do that.With this in mind I was in the process with Amazon to return it but while I couldn't return them at the time I figured I'll hold on to them. I went and connected them to my PC and they auto connect and pair and audio plays beautifully. No hickups whatsoever. I think audio though I get more bass and voices like on a discord call while in gameplay is more closer and clear. So like fps games more roomy and bassy but the voice is contrast with clear and close. But overall they are great for PC use. I disabled the touch controls so they are a standalone Bluetooth earpiece that works seamlessly. Once you have put in the other ear in, you are already getting sound from the PC. This is great as while my overhear headsets charge, I use these and audio switches on there own.

content: I got this because the price was okay and it's recommended as a cheap option for audiophiles. It's an okay product, but I really dislike that it doesn't have physical buttons to press when you want to start/pause something. I disabled the touch sense stuff through the app that it works with, and it seems to ignore the settings I have input. It will still start/pause stuff sometimes, even though the buttons are tied to anything. It also tries to launch "bixby", the mobile assistant thing for Samsung. I don't want to use it - I wish it would stop trying to start on its own.They also don't fit particularly well in the ear. They are okay enough that I can run with them in, but I do have to shove them back in, occasionally because it doesn't have a perfect seal around my ear, which causes them to start slipping after a while. I've tired the various rubber sized ear things that come with it, and none of them really worked any better.The battery life is fine. No complaints.They aren't horrible, but I wish they were priced lower. The overall experience is disappointing.

title: 5.0 out of 5 stars Excellent headphones
author: Flashlight king
content: These headphones have performed excellent for me. Very good sound canceling. I really like the control in the app.What I really would like to add is these headphones are not ear protection. There is I believe a misconception about the difference between noise canceling and noise reducing. If you are mowing or using a blower etc. you need noise REDUCING. Noise cancelling is an artificial noise reduction. It does not protect your ears.I now use a 28db noise reduction over the ear earmuff with the Anker headphones underneath. This works great as I am getting really good noise reduction and still can listen to music. Only need the headphones about 1/3 volume to hear what I want to listen to. Please wear proper hearing protection. Hope this helps.

content: I have tried too many pairs of earbuds, of too many brands, and after reading many many reviews. These are my absolute favorite pair of earbuds. Amazon had them on a deal and they lived up to the reviews in sound, fit and quality. Then unfortunately I misplaced them. Long story short I unknowingly dropped them getting out my car, found them crushed a month later nearby by either my car or the snow plow, the price to replace was too much, and the hunt was on for new earbud replacements. I tried a few lesser from soundcore but they weren't P3s and a few other brands but they didn't have the sound or fit I enjoyed with the Life P3s. If you want earbuds to stay in your ears while eating, bending down, exercising, or just sitting with clear sound and listening to music like it's playing live in front of you, Life P3s are the buds. title: 4.0 out of 5 stars Battery Life is Amazing
author: Corey Helwig
content: Iâ€™m going to compare these to the Apple AirPods Pro, because thatâ€™s what these are replacing for me.I enjoyed my AirPods. But the battery life started off not great, and over time, the earbuds developed some crackling. Finally decided to replace them and these earbuds are what I ordered.The last month or so I used the AirPods, I had to recharge the pack pretty much everyday. The earbuds would drain quickly, Iâ€™d put them back in the the charging case, and the entire charge would be gone within 24 hours.I received these exactly 1 month ago as I write this review. I use these earbuds the same amount I used my AirPods, and Iâ€™m only just now having to plug the case in to recharge it. Itâ€™s completely blown away all my expectations.The sound quality is also much better than the AirPods. The earpieces fit in more securely, and they are equally, if not slightly more comfortable than the AirPods were. I like a lot of bass with my music and these do not disappoint. All around real great quality product and way worth the money.My main criticism is that, compared to the AirPods, the transparency modes leave something to be desired. With the AirPods, I was able to have them in, and be able to hear people talking to me, if I needed to, with the music still playing. With these, I can hear someoneâ€™s voice if theyâ€™re talking to me, but Iâ€™d have to pause whatever Iâ€™m listening to in order to actually hear them. And even at that, the voices still sound muffled in all different transparency modes. So not a dealbreaker, but definitely a little bit of a pain in that regard.

title: 5.0 out of 5 stars Fantastic earbuds
author: A Maurer
content: Our office rearranged the floor plan and I suddenly found myself sitting next to people who are on the phone all day long. I needed some noise canceling earbuds that would block the background noise without costing me $300. Iâ€™ve previously had first gen AirPods and my hustband has the Bose quiet comfort so I had something to compare these to. I also bought a pair of noise canceling jbl earbuds as well as the anker liberty 4 so I could try out multiple and pick which ones I like best.These were the winner for multiple reasons! First off, I genuinely like the look of these over all others I tried (Bose included). The oat white looks expensive and is discrete. Secondly, these fit my ears the best. I have small ears apparently, and the jbls and my husbands Bose quiet comfort were too large and fell out if I turned my head. I found that the anker liberty 4s were slightly more bulky which is part of the reason I ultimately chose these. Thirdly, you canâ€™t beat the price of these. I got a lightning deal that made these only $50. And finally, noise cancellation and sound quality are great! The liberty 4s and Bose block more noise but this was the right amount for me and I like that there are different modes.Highly recommend these! Definitely would not purchase another pair of AirPods again after how great these are!

title: 5.0 out of 5 stars Doesn't hurt and holds a charge forever
author: Failed frugalness
content: I have gone through so many headphones and earbuds. Even my shokz that don't really go on or in your ears would end up hurting after a bit. I was beginning to think I'd never be able to have Bluetooth earbuds because the weight of them was too much or they fit in such a way as to almost instantly hurt. I've had these for almost a year now. After about 7 months they started falling out more so I got the silicone tips that have sort of 2 layers to them and they stay in well. The thing is, I can wear them all day doing the shopping so I don't have to listen to Mariah sing about Christmas or elevator music, and my ears don't hurt at all. These are the first ones I've ever had that I could say that. I also have only charged the case 4 times since I bought them, and only one of those times did it get below 2 dots out of 3 for the charge! The earbuds themselves have never batted an eye at a 2 hour or more outing either.Granted, the noise blocking isn't amazing but it is fine I think. My son is a musician and he says they are ok, but not amazing. I am not as picky as he is though and I think they sound pretty good. The microphone is a typical Bluetooth microphone. People can hear and understand me most of the time but occasionally it gets overloaded by nearby noise or something and I have to use the phone directly.Overall I think they were absolutely worth it. I don't like to give 5 star reviews because I distrust most of them. I can't really think of a reason to discount one star though unless it is because they don't have the same quality as earbuds that cost more than double what these are...but nobody expects them to!

title: 4.0 out of 5 stars Works well, IF you can get them to fit!
author: RJM
content: These buds sound okay, but thatâ€™s not why I bought the P3â€™s. My wife snores, and I needed some way to keep my marriage intact.Previously, I had a very old pair of Bose noise cancelling wired earbuds, but the battery died, and Bose is just too expensive. So I know what good noise cancelling is like, but I wanted something at a more reasonable price point.I was pleasantly surprised at the cancelling performance of the P3 earbuds, and the battery life in noise cancelling when youâ€™re not playing music.Unfortunately, there is one problem.: the stock mushroom heads of the P3â€™s are utterly terrible. You need a good seal in your ear for the cancelling to work, and the design of the stock tips is poor. The various sizes donâ€™t work for different reasons: either they are too small, or they deform in a way that doesnâ€™t make a good seal. I think the engineers at Anker spent almost no time on the ergonomic design.Fortunately, though, I have many after market and leftover mushroom tips and I found one set that isâ€¦ well, better. I still have to keep pushing the earbuds back into my ear holes because they work loose, but I can live with that.Not that anyone will listen, but a future version of these buds should go a little deeper into your ear, and perhaps the rubber could be slightly higher density. Just as a side note, you can buy longer mushroom tips that work okay, but then the earbuds wonâ€™t fit in the charger. Dâ€™oh!

title: 5.0 out of 5 stars Good bass and noise isolation, fit well, overall a really good value
author: Finch
content: They have a bass heavy default sound profile but you can adjust it in the Soundcore app. I donâ€™t really like the controls but those too can be adjusted in the app. I got them on sale for fifty bucks and for the price theyâ€™re very good.Theyâ€™re just as comfortable and quiet as Apple AirPods Pro. I havenâ€™t tested the ANC bc I donâ€™t really use the feature but I do need the noise isolation and its very good. I wish I never wasted the money I did on Apple AirPods. These are a much better value and have no bugs.The things that I donâ€™t like about these:There is a delay when you use the touch sensitive controls, which is just the section of the earbud with the logo. Itâ€™s not the stem. You press the logo and thereâ€™s a half second delay before it takes effect. When you have to double press it makes you wonder if it worked or not. There is a setting in the app to make an audible chime when you press a button. I enabled that and it helps a little. I just wish it was a little faster.The lid on the case is a little flimsy and isnâ€™t held by a magnet. Itâ€™s just a spring loaded hinge.The sound profile is bass heavy. Adjust the highs up in the EQ in the app and it fixed it.Overall Iâ€™m very happy with them! Oh and the battery life is good, at least without ANC on. I listened to them for at least 4-5 hours straight no problem and the battery gauge said it used about half. That was an audiobook on medium volume.

title: 5.0 out of 5 stars Wow, just wow
author: Avalon
content: Preface: I have the Sony XM4 buds right now. Not the XM3, the XM4, the brand new ones. They are the BEST sounding true wireless earbuds I have had thus far, and their battery life is no joke, I canâ€™t kill it. Their current base price is $279.99. (I purchased them for that price)I got the Life P3 for school and just general listening because I didnâ€™t want to risk losing or having my Sonyâ€™s stolen. When I paired and started listening to these earbuds, I couldnâ€™t believe how good they sounded. I actually am starting to have some buyerâ€™s remorse. I like the design of both the buds and the case, theyâ€™re quite sleek and compact. I selected the light blue color, since I donâ€™t like how darker colors show oil from my skin. They fit great and create a good seal which is vital for the best potential bass response. The bass on these buds is no joke, and thatâ€™s coming from Soundcores Signature sound profile, meaning the standard equalizer setting, no customization. Bass is responsive without being too dirty or uncontrolled, mids (where vocals live) are present and clear, and highs are reproduced well without being too sharp. Of course they donâ€™t have the same soundstage or clarity/sharpness as the Sonyâ€™s, but for less than a third of the price itâ€™s almost laughable at how good these buds are by comparison. Let me give you some of my credentials. Iâ€™ve had the:-Sony XM3 & XM4 buds-AirPod Pro-Jabra Elite 75t-Sennheiser Momentum True Wireless 2-Master & Dynamics MW08All of these are some of the best if not the best these manufacturers offer. Music is incredibly important to me and my development as a human being, so I take my sound experience very seriously, doing thorough research and actual hardware/software testing. My three points for a great pair of buds for me is sound/battery/fit. I often listen to music in bed, so fit is important not just for bass. These buds stay in place no problem. The Life P3 companion app by Soundcore is also incredibly useful and modern in its aesthetics and overall design language. It puts the most important settings right in front without being flashy or gimmicky. A great overall experience both for the hardware and software.In short, if you want a great pair of wireless earbuds with great customizable sound, great fit with multiple eartip sizes included in box, good battery life with a case that has wireless charging, and a great app/software experience, look no further. YOU FOUND IT! A great accomplishment for Soundcore and one of the best audio values for consumers.
